p: For the species from China, the EO yield at the blooming stage was reported to range from 0.7 to 1.4% (w/d.w.), according to data of Rodrigues et al. [ 18], reporting for M. pulegium at a full flowering stage has an EO yield of about 1.6% (w./d.w.). On the contrary, the EO yield of the three M. pulegium plants from Sicily ( Figure 1) was higher ranging from 2.7 to 3.2% (v/d.w) for leaves (MPL), and from 2.6 to 2.8% (v/d.w) for flowers (MPF), without significant differences between leaves and flowers ( Table 1). The average EO yield fits perfectly within the range previously reported for other Mentha spp. (1.0â€“3.9%) by Hussain et al. [ 24], approaching the upper limit and confirming that mint plants, which grow in sunny places, characterized by high temperatures and low water supply, have the highest yield in EO [ 25].
